file_metadata.title: Faculty Opinions recommendation of Formin Is Associated with Left-Right Asymmetry in the Pond Snail and the Frog.

chunks.text: Animals exhibit external symmetry but internal asymmetry, with snails showing inherited variation in asymmetry, unlike other animals. Snails and frogs share a common gene for defining left and right, suggesting that asymmetry is an ancient and conserved property of cells and animals.
chunks.chunk_summary: Snails and frogs utilize a common gene to determine left-right asymmetry, indicating that asymmetry is a conserved characteristic in animal cells.
chunks.authors: ["Angus Davison", "Gary S. McDowell", "Jennifer M. Holden", "Harriet F. Johnson", "Georgios D. Koutsovoulos", "Maureen Liu", "Paco Hulpiau", "Frans Van Roy", "Christopher M. Wade", "Ruby Banerjee", "Fengtang Yang", "Angus M. MacNicol", "Cassia Oliveira", "Belen Martin-Blanco", "Mark Blaxter", "Jackson", "Michael Levin", "Mark L. Blaxter"]

chunks.text: Davison et al. identified a cell scaffolding protein in snails and frogs that governs body asymmetry, determining the direction of snail shell coiling and frog heart placement. This suggests that body asymmetry in animals, including humans, likely originates from a conserved intrinsic cell asymmetry.
chunks.chunk_summary: A cell scaffolding protein controls body asymmetry in snails and frogs, suggesting a conserved mechanism for asymmetry across animals.
chunks.authors: ["Angus Davison", "Gary S. McDowell", "Jennifer M. Holden", "Harriet F. Johnson", "Georgios D. Koutsovoulos", "Maureen Liu", "Paco Hulpiau", "Frans Van Roy", "Christopher M. Wade", "Ruby Banerjee", "Fengtang Yang", "Angus M. MacNicol", "Cassia Oliveira", "Belen Martin-Blanco", "Mark Blaxter", "Jackson", "Michael Levin", "Mark L. Blaxter"]

chunks.text: While the pathway components for left-right asymmetry are known in various animals, the initial symmetry-breaking genes in snails remain unknown. This study reports a formin mutation associated with symmetry breaking in pond snails, supported by drug treatments in snails and frogs. Asymmetric gene expression was found in early snail embryos, preceding morphological asymmetry, suggesting that animals with diverse body plans may share intracellular chiral elements for asymmetry.
chunks.chunk_summary: A formin mutation is linked to symmetry breaking in pond snails, with asymmetric gene expression preceding morphological asymmetry, suggesting a conserved mechanism across diverse animal body plans.
chunks.authors: ["Angus Davison", "Gary S. McDowell", "Jennifer M. Holden", "Harriet F. Johnson", "Georgios D. Koutsovoulos", "Maureen Liu", "Paco Hulpiau", "Frans Van Roy", "Christopher M. Wade", "Ruby Banerjee", "Fengtang Yang", "Angus M. MacNicol", "Cassia Oliveira", "Belen Martin-Blanco", "Mark Blaxter", "Jackson", "Michael Levin", "Mark L. Blaxter"]

chunks.text: Bilaterian animals exhibit external symmetry but internal organ asymmetry. The question of how symmetry is broken during development is addressed by a model proposing a chiral "F molecule" oriented relative to the anteroposterior and dorsoventral axes. This asymmetric molecular reference determines left-right differentiation at cellular and organismal levels.
chunks.chunk_summary: A chiral "F molecule" model explains how symmetry is broken during development, establishing left-right differentiation.
chunks.authors: ["Angus Davison", "Gary S. McDowell", "Jennifer M. Holden", "Harriet F. Johnson", "Georgios D. Koutsovoulos", "Maureen Liu", "Paco Hulpiau", "Frans Van Roy", "Christopher M. Wade", "Ruby Banerjee", "Fengtang Yang", "Angus M. MacNicol", "Cassia Oliveira", "Belen Martin-Blanco", "Mark Blaxter", "Jackson", "Michael Levin", "Mark L. Blaxter"]

chunks.text: Despite the importance of chiral patterning in bilaterians, the initial symmetry-breaking steps in Lophotrochozoa remain largely unknown. While commonalities like nodal and pitx signaling molecules exist between vertebrates and snails, these are not the earliest determinants, limiting understanding of deep conservation. Snails, with their genetically tractable chiral variation, offer a unique opportunity to study left-right asymmetry. This study uses genetics, genomics, and pharmacological inhibition to show that the Lymnaea stagnalis chirality gene is a cytoskeletal component, potentially part of an early chiral structure involved in symmetry breaking across Bilateria.
chunks.chunk_summary: Snails, with their variable chirality, provide a model for studying left-right asymmetry, with a cytoskeletal component identified as potentially involved in early symmetry breaking.
chunks.authors: ["Angus Davison", "Gary S. McDowell", "Jennifer M. Holden", "Harriet F. Johnson", "Georgios D. Koutsovoulos", "Maureen Liu", "Paco Hulpiau", "Frans Van Roy", "Christopher M. Wade", "Ruby Banerjee", "Fengtang Yang", "Angus M. MacNicol", "Cassia Oliveira", "Belen Martin-Blanco", "Mark Blaxter", "Jackson", "Michael Levin", "Mark L. Blaxter"]

chunks.text: The chirality of the pond snail Lymnaea stagnalis is controlled by a maternally expressed locus, with the D allele determining a clockwise shell twist. During development, micromeres emerge and twist clockwise in dextral embryos, while sinistral embryos show a later counterclockwise twist. This difference is preceded by chiral spindle orientation in dextral embryos and radial positioning in sinistral embryos. A 0.4 Mb region containing the chirality locus was identified, and a BAC clone walk and genome sequencing were used to pinpoint the gene. Six genes were linked to D, including a pair of duplicated diaphanous-related formin genes (Ldia1 and Ldia2). A frameshift mutation in Ldia2 was found in sinistral snails, and Ldia2 expression was significantly different based on genotype, consistent with nonsense-mediated decay of mutated transcripts. The tandem duplication may explain the non-lethality of the Ldia2 mutation, with Ldia1 and Ldia2 potentially having overlapping roles but also specialized functions, as evidenced by their differential enrichment in embryos versus somatic tissues.
chunks.chunk_summary: A frameshift mutation in the Ldia2 formin gene is associated with sinistral chirality in pond snails, with the tandem duplication of Ldia1 and Ldia2 potentially mitigating lethality.
chunks.authors: ["Angus Davison", "Gary S. McDowell", "Jennifer M. Holden", "Harriet F. Johnson", "Georgios D. Koutsovoulos", "Maureen Liu", "Paco Hulpiau", "Frans Van Roy", "Christopher M. Wade", "Ruby Banerjee", "Fengtang Yang", "Angus M. MacNicol", "Cassia Oliveira", "Belen Martin-Blanco", "Mark Blaxter", "Jackson", "Michael Levin", "Mark L. Blaxter"]

chunks.text: Contrary to expectations, Ldia mRNA showed asymmetric distribution as early as the 2-cell stage in L. stagnalis, becoming largely confined to one macromere by the 4-cell stage. This suggests that individual macromeres have identity earlier than previously thought, challenging existing developmental models. This early asymmetry at the molecular level precedes morphological asymmetry, highlighting the intracellular determination of chirality. The reduced viability of sinistral embryos may be due to conflicts in cell identity caused by incomplete or error-prone chiral rotation of micromeres, supported by less asymmetric staining in sinistral embryos.
chunks.chunk_summary: Asymmetric Ldia mRNA distribution in early snail embryos indicates earlier-than-expected macromere identity and suggests a link between cell identity conflicts and reduced sinistral embryo viability.
chunks.authors: ["Angus Davison", "Gary S. McDowell", "Jennifer M. Holden", "Harriet F. Johnson", "Georgios D. Koutsovoulos", "Maureen Liu", "Paco Hulpiau", "Frans Van Roy", "Christopher M. Wade", "Ruby Banerjee", "Fengtang Yang", "Angus M. MacNicol", "Cassia Oliveira", "Belen Martin-Blanco", "Mark Blaxter", "Jackson", "Michael Levin", "Mark L. Blaxter"]

chunks.text: To investigate formin's role in chirality, the FH2 domain inhibitor SMIFH2 was used. SMIFH2 treatment of dextral embryos resulted in neutral micromere emergence, mimicking the sinistral phenotype. Spindle visualization confirmed radial symmetry in treated dextral embryos, resembling sinistral embryos. The Arp2/3 complex inhibitor CK-666 had a less pronounced effect, suggesting formin-mediated actin assembly is crucial for chiral cleavage orientation. In SMIFH2-treated embryos that developed after neutral micromere emergence, the subsequent twist was dextral, suggesting dextrality as the default pathway. This later twist is actin-dependent, further supporting the idea of dextrality as the default, independent of FH2 domain function.
chunks.chunk_summary: Inhibiting formin with SMIFH2 in dextral snail embryos phenocopies sinistral development, suggesting formin's key role in chiral cleavage orientation, while dextral twisting appears to be the default pathway.
chunks.authors: ["Angus Davison", "Gary S. McDowell", "Jennifer M. Holden", "Harriet F. Johnson", "Georgios D. Koutsovoulos", "Maureen Liu", "Paco Hulpiau", "Frans Van Roy", "Christopher M. Wade", "Ruby Banerjee", "Fengtang Yang", "Angus M. MacNicol", "Cassia Oliveira", "Belen Martin-Blanco", "Mark Blaxter", "Jackson", "Michael Levin", "Mark L. Blaxter"]

chunks.text: Genomic and transcriptomic analysis revealed deep conservation of the chirality locus region, with synteny between L. stagnalis, B. glabrata, and C. telata. The dia duplication, present in L. trunculata, predates its divergence from L. stagnalis, while single-copy dia genes in sinistral snails are more similar to Ldia1. This suggests Ldia2 is the derived paralog with a specialized embryonic function, whose loss leads to sinistrality. Phylogenetic analysis suggests either a single sinistral origin with a reversion to dextrality in Lymnaeidae or two separate sinistral origins. The former is consistent with the dia duplication enabling dextrality in Lymnaeidae.  In other chirally variable snails like Euhadra and Partula, chirality wasn't associated with single-copy dia variation, suggesting additional components in the LR asymmetry pathway.
chunks.chunk_summary: Evolutionary analysis suggests Ldia2 is the derived paralog, with its loss linked to sinistrality, while other snail species may have additional components influencing chirality.
chunks.authors: ["Angus Davison", "Gary S. McDowell", "Jennifer M. Holden", "Harriet F. Johnson", "Georgios D. Koutsovoulos", "Maureen Liu", "Paco Hulpiau", "Frans Van Roy", "Christopher M. Wade", "Ruby Banerjee", "Fengtang Yang", "Angus M. MacNicol", "Cassia Oliveira", "Belen Martin-Blanco", "Mark Blaxter", "Jackson", "Michael Levin", "Mark L. Blaxter"]

chunks.text: While ciliary flow is a model for vertebrate LR symmetry breaking, it's not universal. Cytoskeletal asymmetry could be an ancient mechanism used by vertebrates at early stages. Formin inhibition in early Xenopus laevis embryos affected LR patterning, with SMIFH2 having a stronger effect than CK-666.  Treatment during neurula stages, when ciliary flow is present, showed strong effects for both inhibitors.  Overexpression of mouse dia1 mRNA in frog embryos also resulted in heterotaxia, regardless of injection timing or location.  Targeted injection into specific blastomeres at the 4-cell stage showed no significant difference in heterotaxia effect, suggesting the effect isn't at the point of ciliary flow.
chunks.chunk_summary: Formin inhibition and overexpression in frog embryos disrupt left-right patterning, suggesting a role for formin in early vertebrate development, potentially independent of ciliary flow.
chunks.authors: ["Angus Davison", "Gary S. McDowell", "Jennifer M. Holden", "Harriet F. Johnson", "Georgios D. Koutsovoulos", "Maureen Liu", "Paco Hulpiau", "Frans Van Roy", "Christopher M. Wade", "Ruby Banerjee", "Fengtang Yang", "Angus M. MacNicol", "Cassia Oliveira", "Belen Martin-Blanco", "Mark Blaxter", "Jackson", "Michael Levin", "Mark L. Blaxter"]

chunks.text: The involvement of formin in LR patterning in both molluscs and vertebrates supports the idea of asymmetry as a conserved ancient property.  Diverse body plans may leverage asymmetry from the same intracellular chiral elements. Bilaterian LR asymmetry may depend on the actin cytoskeleton's physical orientation, which causes helical rotation. Formins may play a key role in coordinating functions dependent on both actin and microtubule cytoskeletons. Pond snails offer a tractable model for integrating understanding of downstream patterning genes like nodal and the dynamics of cellular interactions in generating handedness.
chunks.chunk_summary: Formin's role in both mollusc and vertebrate LR patterning suggests a conserved mechanism of asymmetry originating from intracellular chiral elements, with the actin cytoskeleton playing a key role.
